title: Understanding DEXA Scans
content: DEXA scan is a moving X-ray that provides important metrics about body composition. It distinguishes three things: bone, fat, and other. DEXA gives four broad pieces of information: body fat, bone mineral density (BMD), an estimate of visceral adipose tissue (VAT), and appendicular lean mass index (ALMI) and fat-free mass index (FFMI). These measures provide insights into lean mass or muscle mass in the extremities. The radiation levels from a DEXA scan are typically less than 20 microsieverts, which is virtually radiation-free compared to other medical scans. It is recommended to do a DEXA scan once or twice per year.

title: Interpreting DEXA Scan Results
content: DEXA scan results are compared against a population stratified by sex and age to determine where an individual ranks and what interventions may be needed. Body fat is calculated by dividing the total amount of fat by the total mass of the individual. BMD is reported in an absolute amount in grams per centimeter squared and also in a z-score. VAT is estimated based on the amount of fat in the torso, subtracting what is believed to be in the subcutaneous space. ALMI and FFMI are measures of lean mass in the extremities, reported as total amount of lean tissue divided by height in meter squared.

title: Protein Consumption and Muscle Protein Synthesis
content: Dietary protein is essential for muscle protein synthesis. The amount needed, when it should be consumed, and how intake should be divided throughout the day are important considerations. Protein supplements can be used to meet daily intake requirements.

title: Time-Restricted Feeding and Fasting
content: Time-restricted feeding and fasting are dietary strategies that can have health benefits. Time-restricted feeding involves eating within a specific window of time each day, while fasting involves abstaining from food for longer periods. These strategies can influence sleep and circadian rhythm, and may have potential benefits and tradeoffs.

title: Bone Mineral Density (BMD)
content: Bone mineral density (BMD) is shown as the actual grams per centimeter squared. The diagnosis of osteopenia and osteoporosis are typically made off a t-score. When we get these scores, we pay very close attention to lumbar spine, left hip, and right hip. We really want to see z-scores above zero. For somebody with a z-score below zero, it’s probably going to be difficult to increase BMD.

title: Visceral Adipose Tissue (VAT)
content: Visceral adipose tissue (VAT) is included within total body fat. Total body fat is the sum total of all adipose tissue in the entire body. However, everybody has a somewhat genetically predetermined capacity for how much energy they can store. When that subcutaneous area overflows, this excess energy that is the most harmful form of excess energy. It’s really important to get a measurement on VAT because that’s the one that we can capture.

title: Lean Tissue: Appendicular Lean Mass Index (ALMI) and Fat-Free Mass Index (FFMI)
content: Appendicular lean mass index (ALMI) and fat-free mass index (FFMI) are very similar concepts, it’s mass divided by height in kilograms per meter squared. The ALMI is a more accurate representation of muscle mass because it’s saying how much muscle do you have in your arms and your legs. FFMI is used equally, but truthfully has some confounders in there because you’re looking at the entire mass of the individual, which includes organs.

title: Trends in BMD, VAT, & Muscle Mass
content: An obvious trend is that people tend to lose muscle as they age, they add fat mass as they age, and BMD goes down as you age. Therefore, the objective becomes: During what window of time can we actually increase these things before we get to the point where it becomes very difficult to make increases? Another way to state that is, there’s a point at which decline becomes almost inevitable. So you want to be as high as you can, going into that phase.

title: Expectations and Limitations for DEXA Scans
content: Peter discourages patients from ever doing DEXA scans more than twice a year. You have to accept that there’s noise in this system and if you do DEXA scans on two consecutive days, you’re not going to get the same thing. Even though DEXA is still what we consider the gold standard, it’s quite dependent on hydration because remember, it’s differentiating bone, fat, and “other” (and water counts as other).

title: Muscle and Lean Tissue Loss with Age
content: Muscle mass increases significantly between ages 0 and 25, regardless of gender. It then remains relatively stable until around age 35, after which it begins a slow downward trend until age 75, when it drops significantly. Physical activity level follows a similar pattern, rising significantly until age 25 and then remaining relatively stable until age 75, when it also drops significantly. It is unclear whether the decrease in muscle mass drives the reduction in physical activity level, or vice versa. This is referred to as anabolic resistance, which is the difficulty in gaining muscle mass as one ages.

title: Overcoming Anabolic Resistance
content: Anabolic resistance refers to the difficulty in gaining muscle mass as one ages. Factors contributing to anabolic resistance include nutritional, energy signaling, and inflammatory factors. It is important to build muscle mass while young, as it becomes increasingly difficult to do so as one ages. For example, a 30-year-old woman might not perceive the urgency to build muscle mass, whereas a 65-year-old woman might be more motivated to do so due to a shorter time window.

title: DEXA Scan Results and Prescribed Interventions for Female Patients
content: DEXA scan results can provide insights into a patient's health status. For example, a 31-year-old female patient with a Z-score of -0.8 is at risk of becoming osteopenic if she does not take steps to improve her bone health. She is relatively fit but only does non-specific training. Her body fat is about 32% and her ALMI is quite low. The prescribed intervention for her is to reduce intake but increase protein and increase resistance training. Another 45-year-old female patient with a Z-score of -1.2 already has osteopenia. She is undernourished and under muscled. The prescribed intervention for her is to increase her nutritional intake and start resistance training.

title: DEXA Scan Results and Prescribed Interventions for Male Patients
content: A 42-year-old male patient who is overweight and has a body fat percentage of 30% is overnourished but adequately muscled. The prescribed intervention for him is energy restriction without protein restriction, along with a balance of cardio and strength training. Another 55-year-old male patient who is visibly lean and has a body fat percentage of 18% is under muscled. The prescribed intervention for him is to increase his protein intake and start training.

title: Protein Consumption Recommendations
content: The recommended daily intake of protein is somewhere between 1.6 to 2.0 grams per kilogram of body weight. This need can increase over time. For someone who is obese, the recommendation might be modified to two grams per kilogram of lean weight or two grams per kilogram of target weight. Protein should ideally be divided into four portions and spread out throughout the day.

title: Protein Intake and Timing
content: The evidence suggests that 40, 50, maybe up to 60 grams of protein in one sitting can be put to non-metabolic use, meaning non-energy use. Therefore, it is recommended to consume 40 to 50 grams of protein four times a day. The first serving of the day is important in terms of appetite regulation. The meal after a workout is also important, especially for those who are untrained. It is recommended to think more about the day at the macro level as opposed to, how to eat enough protein directly before or after a workout. The more experienced you are in training, the more you can undergo muscle protein synthesis in a longer window post-training event.

title: Protein Supplements and Sugar
content: It’s not necessary to have sugar in protein supplements. It is recommended to use high-quality whey protein for shakes. It is important to strip out everything gratuitous and ensure protein sources are as lean as possible and free from unnecessary refined sugars. Nutrient labels can provide information about protein quality. It is recommended to avoid proprietary blends and nitrogen spiking, and to choose a high-quality whey isolate without a lot of fat and carbohydrates.

title: Protein Intake: Optimal Timing and Division Throughout the Day
content: Protein should be broken up into several meals throughout the day to get the needed daily amount. Consuming too little protein, say 10 grams in a serving, is not optimal as it’s probably going more towards gluconeogenic substrate to make glucose. Similarly, eating one mega dose is also not optimal. If the data suggests 40 to 60 grams is the most you can put to use, then consume 40 to 60 grams. For some people, they only need about three servings a day. For others, it might be five servings a day, depending on the size of the individual.

title: Time-Restricted Feeding (TRF)
content: Time-restricted feeding is one of the strategies to reduce energy intake in over-nourished patients. This means not limiting how many calories you’re eating or what not to eat, but making the window in which you eat narrower. If the window is small enough, most people will probably eat less. However, it’s not clear that an eight-hour window is sufficient to achieve that a deficit. And while something like a one-hour window is likely to achieve a deficit, the big trade off is protein—it’s very difficult to get your total amount of protein in one meal. And even if you do, you likely can’t put it all to use.

title: Prolonged Fasting: Potential Benefits and Tradeoffs
content: There is no evidence that avoiding food 16 hours a day induces autophagy. You’d need to go with at least three days without eating to see biologically and clinically relevant amount of autophagy.

title: Fasting and Weight Loss
content: Fasting is not viewed as a weight loss strategy because weight is typically regained once the fast ends. If you don’t eat for three days, within two days after, you have all that weight back. There are some exceptions where doing a three-day fast once a month, coupled with time-restricted feeding (TRF) and caloric restriction on the other days, was part of the overall strategy. However, fasting should not be primarily considered as a weight loss strategy.

title: Fasting and Biomarkers
content: The case for fasting is based on purging senescent cells, autophagy, and other factors. However, we don’t really have biomarkers for any of these things. A lot of biomarkers get better when you fast, but you don’t need to be fasting to get those benefits. Triglycerides, glucose, insulin, they all get better during a fast, but you don’t have to do something as extreme as fasting to make those things happen. The biomarkers that really matter, we can’t measure yet.

title: Future of Biomarkers
content: The field of metabolomics, combined with proteomics, will be able to unlock a lot of information about biomarkers. With a reasonable amount of computing power which already exists, it’s really just a question of doing the studies. This is expected to happen in the coming decade.

title: Time-Restricted Feeding (TRF) and Protein Supplementation
content: If time-restricted feeding (TRF) is working for you according to all metrics that we have available, by all means, stay with it. There are ways to do TRF a little more intelligently, such as using protein outside of the feeding window. For instance, if you want to do an 18/6 feeding window where you’re committed to eating two big meals between noon and 6:00 PM, it is still encouraged to consume a protein shake that is otherwise relatively low calorie outside of that window.

title: TRF, Sleep and Circadian Rhythm
content: There’s something to be acknowledged between the relationship between food and sleep. It doesn’t make sense to be eating right before bed. Eating your biggest meal at 9:00 PM and then going to bed at 10:00 or 11:00 can lead to higher glucose levels at night, higher cortisol levels at night, and less regulated sleep. The glymphatic system, which removes metabolic waste, is very active at night when you’re sleeping and works more effectively with lower glucose concentration in the blood. Therefore, it is recommended to not eat within ideally three hours before bed.

title: Alcohol and Sleep
content: Consuming alcohol close to bedtime can be disruptive for sleep. It’s not really going to be contributing much to glucose levels, but it’s certainly going to be contributing to aldehydes and things that are going to be highly disruptive for sleep. There’s no upside to consuming anything than a little bit of water in that three-hour window before bed.
